description:
Brassica napus, commonly known as rapeseed or canola, is a species of flowering plant in the family Brassicaceae. It is an important crop cultivated for its edible oil and meal, which is used in various food and industrial applications.

Brassica napus is a diploid species, having 38 chromosomes (2n = 38). It is believed to have originated as a natural hybrid between two other Brassica species, Brassica rapa (syn. Brassica campestris) and Brassica oleracea.

The plant is an annual or biennial herb, typically reaching a height of 0.5 to 1.5 meters. It has a well-developed taproot system and produces multiple branching stems. The leaves are glaucous (with a waxy, blue-green appearance) and vary in shape from deeply lobed to entire. The flowers are bright yellow, typically arranged in terminal racemes, and have four petals in a cruciform arrangement, characteristic of the Brassicaceae family.

Brassica napus is cultivated for its high-quality edible oil, which is extracted from the seeds. The oil is low in erucic acid and has a neutral flavor, making it suitable for various culinary and industrial applications. The leftover meal after oil extraction is also used as a protein-rich animal feed.

Rapeseed is an important crop globally, particularly in regions with temperate climates. It is widely grown in countries such as Canada, China, India, and parts of Europe. Brassica napus is also valued for its potential as a biofuel crop, with the oil being used in the production of biodiesel.
